hints.content:
##Problem 1: Flower height and petal length

Sean measured the height and petal length (in centimeters) of all the flowers in his garden.  
  
|||||||
:-- | --: | --: | --: | --: | --: | --: 
**Height $(\text{cm})$** | $30$ | $20$ | $15$ | $35$ | $10$ | $40$ 
**Petal length $(\text{cm})$**| $6$ | $4$ | $2$ | $8$ | $1.5$ | $8.5$

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

[[☃ graded-group 2]]  
[[☃ explanation 5]]

[[☃ graded-group 3]]  
[[☃ explanation 9]]

options.explanation:
Let's plot each point, with its $x$-coordinate coming from the *height* and the $y$-coordinate coming from the corresponding *petal length*.

The final graph looks like this:  
  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/333b06f6d658c349663413f67435ea2d2bb5895a)

An example of each type of correlation is shown below. 

$\greenD{\text{Positive correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2fa017d9cd398ffcc94396fb5300fb01415eb70c)

$\maroonD{\text{Negative correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7369fbf2eb900d2a7b7ec4f8502859ac5ef88e80)

$\goldD{\text{No correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/546edc63617e4a9980f6874288f4a6c949f22a9a)

The answer for Sam's flowers:

Positive correlation

We can look at it this way:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/016eb38387c9d8aca24ccfbb6462446da7b00352)

The answer:

Taller flowers tended to have longer petals.

options.content:
**a) Plot the data in a scatterplot.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

**b) What is the best description of the relationship between height and petal length for Sam's flowers?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

**c) Which statement is the most accurate interpretation of the correlation?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: Taller flowers tended to have shorter petals.
Taller flowers tended to have longer petals.
There was no clear relationship between flower height and petal length.

hints.content:
##Problem 2: Car driver age

Data was recorded on the age of drivers and the number of car accidents per $100$ drivers in the year $2009$. The data is shown in the scatter plot below.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ffa167e6740a1093649c055b2edff49e66268c7d)

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

[[☃ graded-group 2]]  
[[☃ explanation 2]]

options.explanation:
An example of each type of correlation is shown below. 

$\greenD{\text{Positive correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2fa017d9cd398ffcc94396fb5300fb01415eb70c)

$\maroonD{\text{Negative correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7369fbf2eb900d2a7b7ec4f8502859ac5ef88e80)

$\goldD{\text{No correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/546edc63617e4a9980f6874288f4a6c949f22a9a)

The answer:

Negative correlation

We can look at it this way:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4dca991398791176acef23ae38c7c644fd139db0)

The answer:

Older drivers tended to have fewer accidents.

options.content:
**a) What is the best description of the relationship between age and the number of car accidents?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

**b) Which statement is the most accurate interpretation of the correlation?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: The older drivers tended to have fewer accidents.
The older drivers tended to have more accidents.
There was no clear relationship between age and the number of accidents.

hints.content:
##Problem 3: Shoe sizes and test scores

Dexter's class recorded data on the test grades and shoe sizes of students in the class. The data is shown in the scatter plot below.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f6796dc096fa83db33f8cda991c286a591801f17)

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

[[☃ graded-group 2]]  
[[☃ explanation 2]]

options.explanation:
An example of each type of correlation is shown below. 

$\greenD{\text{Positive correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2fa017d9cd398ffcc94396fb5300fb01415eb70c)

$\maroonD{\text{Negative correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7369fbf2eb900d2a7b7ec4f8502859ac5ef88e80)

$\goldD{\text{No correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/546edc63617e4a9980f6874288f4a6c949f22a9a)

The answer:

No correlation

There doesn't seem to be any correlation between shoe size and test scores; the scores are about as high for students with big feet as for students with small feet.

The answer:

There was no clear relationship between shoe size and test scores.

options.content:
**a) What is the best description of the relationship between shoe size and test scores?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

**b) Which statement is the most accurate interpretation of the correlation?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: Students with bigger shoe sizes tended to score higher on the test.
Students with bigger shoe sizes tended to score lower on the test.
There was no clear relationship between shoe size and test scores.

question.content: We make scatterplots to see relationships between variables. Scatterplots are really good for helping us see if two variables have positive or negative correlation (or no correlation at all).

hints.content:
Paige collected data on how long she spent on her phone compared to how much battery life was remaining (in hours) throughout the day. Here is the data:

|||||||||
:-- | --: | --: | --: | --: | --: | --: | --: | --: | --: | --: | --: | --: |  
**Time spent on phone (hours)** | $1$ | $2$ | $3.5$ | $4$ | $6$ | $7$ | $8$ | $9$
**Battery life remaining (hours)**| $8$ | $7$ | $7$ | $5.5$ | $5$ | $3.5$ | $2.5$ | $2.5$

She then made this scatterplot:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/63f5d2b76630254df001348915bf25c26c0fcb0e)

Now she wants a trend line to describe the relationship between how much time she spent on phone and the battery life remaining. She drew three possible trend lines:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5ed24e3ffc6004e7cb4a2f3d8ca0a5af4a31bb4d)

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
A trend line fits the data when it goes through the middle of the data points.

Line $\maroonD{\text{A}}$ fits the data.

options.content:
**1) Which line fits the data graphed above?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: None of the lines fit the data.

hints.content:
[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
We need the slope and the $y$-intercept to find the equation of the trend line.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9d1ede42dce7c0b3f84523526087ec30298fe812)

This line goes through $(0,9)$ and $(4,6)$, so the slope is $\dfrac{6-9}{4-0} = -\dfrac34=-0.75$.

We can see that the line passes through $(0,9)$, so the $y$-intercept is $9$.

The equation that best describes the trend line is $y=-0.75x+9$.

options.content:
**2) Which equation describes the best trend line above?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
[[☃ graded-group 1]]

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The $x$ variable represents phone use, so plug in $3.6$ for $x$ in the trend line equation $y=-0.75x+9 $ to find out the predicted battery life after $3.6$ hours of phone use.

$\begin{align}y&=-0.75x+9\\
y&=-0.75(3.6)+9\\
y&=-2.7+9\\
y&=6.3\end{align}$

The predicted battery life is $6.3$ hours.

options.content:
**3) Use the equation of the trend line to predict the battery life remaining after $3.6$ hours of phone use.**  
*Round your answer to the nearest tenth of an hour.*

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] hours

hints.content:
[[☃ graded-group 1]]

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The $x$ variable represents phone use, and the $y$ variable represents battery life remaining, so plug in $1$ for $y$ in the trend line equation $y=-0.75x+9 $ to find out how many hours of use it will take until there is only $1$ hour of predicted battery life remaining.

$\begin{align}y&=-0.75x+9~~~~~~\small\gray{\text{Plug in 1 for }y}\\
1&=-0.75x+9~~~~~~\small\gray{\text{Subtract 9 from each side}}\\
-8&=-0.75x~~~~~~~~~~~~~\small\gray{\text{Divide by -0.75 on both sides}}\\
y&\approx10.7\end{align}$

It takes about $10.7$ hours of use.

options.content:
**4) According to the trend line equation, how many hours of use does it take until there is only $1$ hour of predicted battery life remaining?**  
*Round your answer to the nearest tenth of an hour.*

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] hours

hints.content:
[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The $x$ variable represents phone use, so plug in $20$ for $x$ in the trend line equation $y=-0.75x+9 $ to find out the predicted battery life after $20$ hours of phone use.

$\begin{align}y&=-0.75x+9\\
y&=-0.75(20)+9\\
y&=-15+9\\
y&=-6\end{align}$

The predicted battery life is $-6$ hours.

options.content:
**5) Use the trend line to predict the battery life remaining after $20$ hours of phone use.**

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] hours

hints.content:
[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
We should use caution when making predictions that go beyond the pattern in the data we have, which is called extrapolation.

We see a pattern from $x=1$  to $x=9$ hours, but that pattern is not guaranteed to continue past $x=9$ hours. In fact, it can't continue much longer, because the battery dies when its $y$ value is $0$.

Saying we predict $-6$ hours of battery life remaining after $20$ hours of phone use doesn't make much sense, so we shouldn't use that prediction.

options.content:
**6) Does the prediction from question 5 seem reasonable in the context of the problem?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: Yes. Plugging in $20$ gave us a prediction of $-6$ hours.
No. It doesn't make sense for battery life to be negative in this context.

hints.content:
[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The slope of the trend line represents the predicted change in the vertical variable that's associated with a one-unit change in the horizontal variable.

In this case, the slope represents the predicted change in battery life remaining associated with a $1$ hour increase in time spent on the phone.

$\text{slope}=\dfrac{\text{rise}}{\text{run}}=\dfrac{-3}{4}=\dfrac{-0.75}{4}$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6724c1b6110de6b30b63f274cd95c7aaefb2085a)

The answer:

For each additional $1$ hour of time spent on the phone, the predicted battery life remaining decreases by $0.75$ hours.

options.content:
**7) What is the best interpretation of the slope of this trend line?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: For each additional $1$ hour of time spent on the phone, the predicted battery life remaining increases by $0.75$ hours.
For each additional $1$ hour of time spent on the phone, the predicted battery life remaining decreases by $0.75$ hours.
For each additional $0.75$ hours of time spent on the phone, the predicted battery life remaining decreases by $1$ hour.

hints.content:
[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The $y$-intercept of the model describes the predicted $y$ value when $x = 0$. 

In this case, $x = 0$ refers to $0$ hours spent on the phone since the $x$ variable is defined as time spent on the phone.

The answer:

When the time spent on her phone is $0$ hours, the predicted battery life remaining is $9$ hours.

options.content:
**8) What is the best interpretation of the $y$-intercept of this trend line?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: When the time spent on her phone is $9$ hours, the predicted battery life remaining is $0$ hours.
When the time spent on her phone is $0$ hours, the predicted battery life remaining is $9$ hours.

hints.content:
### Challenge question

Paige wants to turn her phone off when the battery has $15$ minutes remaining, just in case she has an emergency and needs her phone later.

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The $x$ variable represents phone use in hours, and the $y$ variable represents battery life remaining in hours. Convert $15$ minutes to $\dfrac14$ hour. Then plug in $\dfrac14$ for $y$ in the trend line equation $y=-0.75x+9 $ to find out how many hours of use it will take until there is only $\dfrac14$ hour of predicted battery life remaining.

$\begin{align}y&=-0.75x+9~~~~~~\small\gray{\text{Plug in } \dfrac14 \text{for }y}\\
\\
\dfrac14&=-0.75x+9~~~~~~\small\gray{\text{Subtract 9 from each side}}\\
\\
-8.75&=-0.75x~~~~~~~~~~~~~\small\gray{\text{Divide by -0.75 on both sides}}\\
\\
y&\approx11.7\end{align}$

She can spend about $11.7$ hours on her phone before turning it off.

options.content:
**According to the trend line, how long can she spend on her phone before she needs to turn it off?**  
*Round your answer to the nearest tenth of an hour.*

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] hours

name: [Context] Equations of trend lines: phone data

hints.content:
### Part 1: The mean

A golf team's $6$ members had the scores below in their most recent tournament:

$70,\,72,\,74,\,76,\,80,\,114$

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

[[☃ graded-group 2]]  
[[☃ explanation 2]]

options.explanation:
The mean is the sum of the scores divided by the number of scores.

$\text{mean}=\dfrac{70+72+74+76+80+114}{6}=\dfrac{486}{6}=81$

The mean is $81$.

The mean is the sum of the scores divided by the number of players. It is not necessarily in the exact middle where half the team scored higher and half scored lower.

So it represents the "average" score. If each golfer had scored the same, they each would have scored the mean.

options.content:
**a) Calculate the mean score.**

mean = [[☃ numeric-input 1]]

**b) What is a correct interpretation of the mean score?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: It is the middle point in the set of scores. That is, half the team scored higher than the mean, and half the the team scored lower than the mean.
It represents the "average" score. If each golfer had scored the same, they each would have scored the mean.

hints.content:
### Part 2: The median

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

[[☃ graded-group 2]]  
[[☃ explanation 2]]

options.explanation:
The median is the middle point in an ordered data set.

If there is an even number of data points, the median is the average of the middle two points.

$70,\,72,\,\blueD{74},\,\blueD{76},\,80,\,114$

$\text{median}=\dfrac{\blueD{74}+\blueD{76}}{2}=\dfrac{150}{2}=75$

The median is $75$.

Three of the six golfers were below the median and the other three were above.

So it is the middle point in the set of scores. That is, half the team scored higher than the median, and half the the team scored lower than the median.

options.content:
**a) Find the median score.**  
*As a reminder, here are the scores:* $~~70,\,72,\,74,\,76,\,80,\,114$

median = [[☃ numeric-input 1]]

**b) What is a correct interpretation of the median score?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: It is the middle point in the set of scores. That is, half the team scored higher than the median, and half the the team scored lower than the median.
It is the "average" score. That is, if each golfer had scored the same, they each would have scored the median.

hints.content:
### Part 3: The "best" measure of center

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The "best" measure should be representative of a "typical" score in this data set. Did most of the golfers on the team score around the mean, or the median?

The golfer who scored $114$ is an outlier because they scored much higher than the rest of the team. Because there is a high outlier, the median is the best measure to describe the scores. The mean of $81$ is higher than every score but one, so it doesn't represent the scores very well.

The median is best because, the mean is higher than almost all of the scores in the data set.

options.content:
**Which measure best describes the scores of the team?**  
*As a reminder, here are the scores:* $~~70,\,72,\,74,\,76,\,80,\,114$

The [[☃ dropdown 1]] best describes the scores of the team, because the [[☃ dropdown 2]] is higher than almost all of the scores in the data set.

question.content: Mean and median both try to measure the "central tendency" in a data set. The goal of each is to get an idea of a "typical" value in the data set. The mean is commonly used, but sometimes the median is preferred.

name: [Gap] Choosing the "best" measure of center: golf scores

hints.content:
## Part 1: The range

Ron recorded the daily high temperatures for two different cities in a recent week  in degree Celsius. The temperatures for each city are shown below.
  
Kansas City, MO: $~23,\,25,\,28,\,28,\,32,\,33,\,35$

Paradise, MI: $~16,\,24,\,26,\,26,\,26,\,27,\,28$

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

[[☃ graded-group 2]]  
[[☃ explanation 2]]

[[☃ graded-group 3]]  
[[☃ explanation 3]]

[[☃ graded-group 4]]  
[[☃ explanation 4]]

options.explanation:
$\text{range}=\blueD{\text{max}}-\greenD{\text{min}}$

$\greenD{23},\,25,\,28,\,28,\,32,\,33,\,\blueD{35}$

$\text{range}=\blueD{35}-\greenD{23}$

$\text{range}=12$

$\text{range}=\blueD{\text{max}}-\greenD{\text{min}}$

$\greenD{16},\,24,\,26,\,26,\,26,\,27,\,\blueD{28}$

$\text{range}=\blueD{28}-\greenD{16}$

$\text{range}=12$

The range is calculated by subtracting the lowest temperature from the highest temperature. This gives the amount of spread between the lowest and highest data points.

The range represents how far apart the lowest and the highest measurements were that week.

The range measures the amount of spread or variability between the lowest and highest data points. Each city had a range of $12$.

According to the ranges, the temperatures in each city had the same amount of variability.

options.content:
**a) Calculate the range of the temperatures in Kansas City, MO.**

range = [[☃ numeric-input 1]]

**b) Calculate the range of the temperatures in Paradise, MI.**

range = [[☃ numeric-input 1]]

**c) What is the best interpretation of the range?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: The range represents the typical temperature that week.
The range represents how far apart the lowest and the highest measurements were that week.
The range represents the amount of spread in the middle half of the data that week.

options.content:
**d) According to the ranges, which city's temperatures were more varied in that week?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: According to the ranges, the temperatures varied more in Paradise, MI.
According to the ranges, the temperatures varied more in Kansas City, MO.
According to the ranges, the temperatures in each city had the same amount of variability.

hints.content:
## Part 2: The interquartile range (IQR)

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

[[☃ graded-group 2]]  
[[☃ explanation 2]]

[[☃ graded-group 3]]  
[[☃ explanation 3]]

[[☃ graded-group 4]]  
[[☃ explanation 5]]

options.explanation:
$\text{IQR}=\maroonC{Q_3}-\goldC{Q_1}$

Step 1) Find the median

$23,25,28,\purpleD{\large28},32,33,35$

$\text{Median} = \purpleD{28}$ 

Step 2) Find the quartiles. The lower quartile $(Q_1)$ is the median of the data below the median. The upper quartile $(Q_3)$ is the median of the data above the median.

$23,\goldC{\large25},28,\purpleD{\large28},32,\maroonC{\large33},35$

$ Q_1 = \goldC{25}$
 
$ Q_3 = \maroonC{33}$

Step 3) Calculate IQR.

$\begin{align} \text{IQR}&=\maroonC{Q_3}-\goldC{Q_1} \\
\\
&=\maroonC{33}-\goldC{25} \\
\\
&=8 \end{align}$

$\text{IQR}=\maroonC{Q_3}-\goldC{Q_1}$

Step 1) Find the median

$16,24,26,\purpleD{\large26},26,27,28$

$\text{Median} = \purpleD{26}$ 

Step 2) Find the quartiles. The lower quartile $(Q_1)$ is the median of the data below the median. The upper quartile $(Q_3)$ is the median of the data above the median.

$16,\goldC{\large24},26,\purpleD{\large26},26,\maroonC{\large27},28$

$ Q_1 = \goldC{24}$
 
$ Q_3 = \maroonC{27}$

Step 3) Calculate IQR.

$\begin{align} \text{IQR}&=\maroonC{Q_3}-\goldC{Q_1} \\
\\
&=\maroonC{27}-\goldC{24} \\
\\
&=3 \end{align}$

The IQR is calculated by subtracting $Q_1$ from $Q_3$, so it is the distance from $Q_1$ to $Q_3$. About $50\%$ of the data is between $Q_1$ and $Q_3$.

The IQR approximates the amount of spread in the middle half of the data that week.

The IQR measures the amount of spread or variability in the middle half of the data points. The temperatures in Kansas City has a larger IQR.

According to the IQRs, the temperatures varied more in Kansas City, MO.

options.content:
**a) Calculate the IQR of the temperatures in Kansas City, MO.**  
*As a reminder, here are the temperatures:* $~23,\,25,\,28,\,28,\,32,\,33,\,35$

IQR = [[☃ numeric-input 1]]

**b) Calculate the IQR of the temperatures in Paradise, MI.**  
*As a reminder, here are the temperatures:* $~~16,\,24,\,26,\,26,\,26,\,27,\,28$

IQR = [[☃ numeric-input 1]]

**c) What is the best interpretation of the IQR?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: The IQR represents the typical temperature that week.
The IQR represents how far apart the lowest and the highest measurements were that week.
The IQR approximates the amount of spread in the middle half of the data that week.

options.content:
**d) According to the IQRs, which city's temperatures were more varied in that week?**


[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: According to the IQRs, the temperatures varied more in Paradise, MI.
According to the IQRs, the temperatures varied more in Kansas City, MO.
According to the IQRs, the temperatures in each city had the same amount of variability.

hints.content:
## Part 3: Comparing range and IQR

Ron made a dot plot for the temperatures in each city.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/028c98d694206c22e06d311100047c2d51a6b64e)

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

[[☃ graded-group 2]]  
[[☃ explanation 2]]

options.explanation:
Individual dots are more spread out from each other in the Kansas City data, while they are clustered closer together in the Paradise data. Temperatures vary more when they are farther apart.

Temperatures in Kansas City, MO seemed to vary more from day to to day, because individual dots are more spread out from each other.

The first statement is true. If we ignore the low outlier in the Paradise data, the range in the temperatures is only $4^{\circ}\text{C}$ instead of $12^{\circ}\text{C}$.

The second statement is true. The Kansas City data had a larger IQR and its temperatures appeared to vary more from day to day.

The third statement is false. The range for both data sets was the same.

options.content:
**a) Looking at the dot plot, which city's temperatures seem to be more varied from day to day?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: Temperatures in Kansas City, MO seemed to vary more from day to to day, because individual dots are more spread out from each other.
Temperatures in Paradise, MI seemed to vary more from day to day because individual dots are clustered closer together.

options.content:
**b) Why might IQR be preferred to measure of spread in this context?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: The low outlier in the Paradise temperatures has a large impact on the range of that data set, while IQR is not impacted by the outlier.
The IQR was larger in the Kansas City data, which reflects how the temperatures generally seemed to vary more from day to day in Kansas City than they did in Paradise.
The range shows that the data is more clustered in Paradise.

question.content: Range and interquartile range (IQR) both measure the "spread" in a data set. Looking at spread let us see how much data varies. Range is a quick way to get an idea of spread. It takes longer to find the IQR, but it sometimes gives us more useful information about spread.

name: [Gap] Finding range and interquartile range: Temperatures

hints.content:
##Part 1: Calculating standard deviation

Ron recorded the daily high temperatures for St. Louis, MO in a recent week  in degree Celsius. The temperatures  are shown below.
  
$23,\,25,\,27,\,28,\,32,\,33,\,35$

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
Step 1) Find the mean:

$\bar{x} = \dfrac{23+25 + 27 + 28+32+33+35}{7} = \dfrac{203}{7} =  \blueD{29}$

Step 2) For each data point, find the square of its distance to the mean. 

Data point $x$ |Square of the distance from the mean $\lvert x - \bar{x} \rvert^2$ 
:-: | :-: | :-: 
 $23$ | $\lvert 23 - \blueD{29} \rvert^2=6^2=36$
 $25$  | $\lvert 25 - \blueD{29} \rvert^2=4^2=16$ 
 $27$ | $\lvert 27 - \blueD{29} \rvert^2=2^2=4$
 $28$ | $\lvert 28 - \blueD{29} \rvert^2=1^2=1$
 $32$ | $\lvert 32 - \blueD{29} \rvert^2=3^2=9$
 $33$ | $\lvert 33 - \blueD{29} \rvert^2=4^2=16$
 $35$ | $\lvert 35 - \blueD{29} \rvert^2=6^2=36$

Step 3) Sum the values from Step 2.

$36+16+4+1+9+16+36=118$

Step 4) Divide by the number of data points.

$\dfrac{118}{7}\approx16.9$

Step 5) Take the square root.

$\sqrt{\dfrac{118}{7}}\approx4.1$

The standard deviation is about $4.1^\circ \text{C}$.

options.content:
**Calculate the standard deviation of the temperatures in St. Louis.**  
*Round your answer to the nearest tenth of a degree.*

standard deviation = [[☃ numeric-input 1]] $^\circ \text{C}$

hints.content:
##Part 2: Interpreting standard deviation

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
Standard deviation comes from measuring the distance between each data point and the mean.

It represents the typical difference between the temperature each day and the mean temperature that week.

options.content:
**What is the best interpretation of the standard deviation for the temperatures in St. Louis?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: It represents the typical difference between the mean and median temperatures that week.
It represents the typical difference between the temperature each day and the mean temperature that week.
It represents how different the temperature was each day from the day before it that week.

hints.content:
##Part 3: Using standard deviation to analyze the data

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
One standard deviation below the mean is $29-4.1=24.9$

One standard deviation above the mean is $29+4.1=33.1$

We can count how many data points are between $24.9$ and $33.1$:

$23$, $\large{\maroonD{25}}$, $\large{\maroonD{27}}$, $\large{\maroonD{28}}$, $\large{\maroonD{32}}$, 
$\large{\maroonD{33}}$, $35$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/69bfcf6dc94cb1a1fd34c77407cde0f7eed5c8f3)

The answer:

$5$ of the $7$ days were within $1$ standard deviation of the mean.

options.content:
**How many of the temperatures in St. Louis were within $1$ standard deviation of the mean?**  
*As a reminder, here are the temperatures:* $~~23,\,25,\,27,\,28,\,32,\,33,\,35$

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] of the $7$ days were within $1$ standard deviation of the mean.

question.content: Standard deviation measures "spread" in a data set by finding the typical distance between each data point and the mean in a set of data.

hints.content:
##Problem 1: Qualitative and quantitative data

A survey was given that included data on each student's field of interest, age in years, number of languages spoken, and handedness.

 | David | Becca | Paige | ...
- | - | - | - | -
**Field of interest** | computer science | journalism | chemistry | ...
**Age (years)** | $13$ | $15$ | $14$ | ...
**Languages spoken** | $2$ | $1$ | $1$ | ...
**Handed**| right | left | right | ...

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

[[☃ graded-group 2]]  
[[☃ explanation 2]]

[[☃ graded-group 3]]  
[[☃ explanation 3]]

[[☃ graded-group 4]]  
[[☃ explanation 4]]

options.explanation:
The data in "field of interest" are names of categories instead of numerical measurements.

This is qualitative data.

The data in "age (years)" are numerical quantities that came from a measurement.

This is quantitative data.

The data in "languages spoken" are numerical quantities that came from a measurement.

This is quantitative data.

The data in "handed" are names of categories instead of numerical measurements.

This is qualitative data.

options.content:
**a) Is "field of interest" qualitative or quantitative?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

**b) Is "age (years)" qualitative or quantitative?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

**c) Is "languages spoken" qualitative or quantitative?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

**d) Is "handed" qualitative or quantitative?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
##Problem 2: Representative samples

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

[[☃ graded-group 2]]  
[[☃ explanation 2]]

options.explanation:
Students at a football game may like watching sports more than students who don't go to football games.

If Jillian wants to know about the students at her school, she should sample in a way that gives every student at her school an equal chance of being in the sample.

The answer for a more representative sample:

At the next school assembly, ask every third student who enters whether or not they watch sports on TV.

Students who respond to an email may be more likely to have a computer than students who don't respond to an email.

If Theo wants to know about the students at his school, he should sample in a way that gives every student at his school an equal chance of being in the sample.

The answer for a more representative sample:

Get an alphabetized list of the names of all students in the school, and pick every tenth student on the list to survey.

options.content:
**a) Jillian wants to know what percent of students at her school watch sports on TV. Which strategy for sampling will be more likely to produce a representative sample?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: At the next school football game, ask every third student who enters whether or not they watch sports on TV.
At the next school assembly, ask every third student who enters whether or not they watch sports on TV.

options.content:
**b) Theo wants to know what percent of students at his school have a computer. Which strategy for sampling will be more likely to produce a representative sample?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: Get an alphabetized list of the names of all students in the school, and pick every tenth student on the list to survey.
Send an email to every student asking them if they have a computer, and count the first $50$ surveys that get returned.

hints.content:
##Problem 3: Sampling methods

Willy wants to find what percent of students at his school drink the milk after they finish their cereal. He is considering the following sampling methods:

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

[[☃ graded-group 2]]  
[[☃ explanation 2]]

[[☃ graded-group 3]]  
[[☃ explanation 3]]

[[☃ graded-group 4]]  
[[☃ explanation 4]]

options.explanation:
The students are in order and every $\text{n}^{\text{th}}$ student is included in the sample.

This is systematic sampling.

The students are separated into groups (grade levels) and a random sample of students is taken from each group. Those samples are put together to form the overall sample.

Sampling some members from all of the groups is stratified sampling.

This is stratified sampling.

Each student in the population has an equal chance of being in the sample.

This is random sampling.

The students are separated into groups (classrooms) and some of the groups are chosen at random. All the members of those chosen groups are in the sample.

Sampling all the members from some of the groups is cluster sampling.

This is cluster sampling.

options.content:
**a) He selects every tenth person who enters the school. What type of sampling is this?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

**b) He randomly selects $10$ students from each grade level (freshman, sophomore, junior, senior). What type of sampling is this?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

**c) He randomly selects $50$ student names from a hat. What type of sampling is this?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

**d) He randomly selects $3$ classrooms and surveys every student in those classrooms. What type of sampling is this?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
##Problem 4: Biased wording in survey questions

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The first choice is biased because the wording suggests that drinking the milk is a good thing by mentioning wastefulness and money.

The third choice is biased because the wording suggests that drinking the milk is a bad thing by mentioning it is disgusting.

The second choice is the most unbiased.

options.content:
**Willy wants to find what percent of students drink the milk after they finish their cereal. Which survey question below is the most unbiased?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: "Do you reduce waste and save money by drinking the milk after you finish your cereal?"
"Do you drink the milk after you finish your cereal?"
"Do you drink the disgusting leftover milk after you finish your cereal?"

question.content: When we collect data it's important to know what type of data we're collecting and how to collect it properly.

hints.content:
##Part 1: Making a relative frequency table

A university surveyed its students on their opinions of campus housing. The following two-way table displays data for the sample of $200$ students who responded to the survey.


Gender | Positive opinion | Negative opinion | Neutral opinion | TOTAL
- | :-: |:-: | :-: | :-:
Male | $40$ | $36$ | $14$ | $90$
Female | $42$ | $56$ | $12$ | $110$
**TOTAL** | $82$ | $92$ | $26$ | $200$

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
Divide each count by its row total to get the relative frequencies.

Gender | Positive opinion | Negative opinion | Neutral opinion | TOTAL
- | :-: |:-: | :-: | :-:
Male | $\dfrac{40}{90}\approx44\%$ | $\dfrac{36}{90}=40\%$ | $\dfrac{14}{90}\approx16\%$ | $\dfrac{90}{90}=100\%$
Female | $\dfrac{42}{110}\approx38\%$ | $\dfrac{56}{110}\approx51\%$ | $\dfrac{12}{110}\approx11\%$ | $\dfrac{110}{110}=100\%$

options.content:
**Complete the following two-way table of row relative frequencies.**   
*(If necessary, round your answers to the nearest percent.)*

Gender | Positive opinion | Negative opinion | Neutral opinion | TOTAL
- | :-: |:-: | :-: | :-:
Male | [[☃ numeric-input 1]] $\%$ | [[☃ numeric-input 2]] $\%$ | [[☃ numeric-input 3]] $\%$ |  $100\%$
Female | [[☃ numeric-input 4]] $\%$ | [[☃ numeric-input 5]] $\%$ | [[☃ numeric-input 6]] $\%$ |  $100\%$

hints.content:
##Part 2: Reading a relative frequency table

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]


[[☃ graded-group 3]]  
[[☃ explanation 4]]

options.explanation:
Gender | Positive opinion | Negative opinion | Neutral opinion | TOTAL
- | :-: |:-: | :-: | :-:
Male | $\dfrac{40}{90}\approx44\%$ | $\blueD{\dfrac{36}{90}=40\%}$ | $\dfrac{14}{90}\approx16\%$ | $\dfrac{90}{90}=100\%$
Female | $\dfrac{42}{110}\approx38\%$ | $\dfrac{56}{110}\approx51\%$ | $\dfrac{12}{110}\approx11\%$ | $\dfrac{110}{110}=100\%$

$36$ of $90$ males had a negative opinion of campus housing, which is $40\%$.

Gender | Positive opinion | Negative opinion | Neutral opinion | TOTAL
- | :-: |:-: | :-: | :-:
Male | $\dfrac{40}{90}\approx44\%$ | $\dfrac{36}{90}=40\%$ | $\dfrac{14}{90}\approx16\%$ | $\dfrac{90}{90}=100\%$
Female | $\dfrac{42}{110}\approx38\%$ | $\blueD{\dfrac{56}{110}\approx51\%}$ | $\dfrac{12}{110}\approx11\%$ | $\dfrac{110}{110}=100\%$

$56$ of $110$ females had a negative opinion of campus housing, which is about $51\%$.

options.content:
**What percent of males had a negative opinion of campus housing?**  
*Round your answer to the nearest percent.*

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] %

**What percent of females had a negative opinion of campus housing?**  
*Round your answer to the nearest percent.*

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] %

hints.content:
##Part 3: Seeing a relationship in a two-way relative frequency table

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  
[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
We saw that $40\%$ of males had a negative opinion of housing, while about $51\%$ of females had a negative opinion of housing.

So there is an association between gender and opinion. Females are more likely to have a negative opinion of campus housing.

options.content:
**Based on the relative frequencies from above, which is a valid conclusion about the relationship between gender and opinion in this data?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: There is an association between gender and opinion. Males are more likely to have a negative opinion of campus housing.
There is an association between gender and opinion. Females are more likely to have a negative opinion of campus housing.
There is no assocation between gender and opinion.

question.content: Two-way relative frequency tables show us percentages rather than counts. They are good for seeing if there is an association between two variables.

name: [Context] Two-way relative frequency tables and associations

qualitative

 | David | Becca | Paige | ...

quantitative

**b) Is "age (years)" qualitative or quantitative?**

 | David | Becca | Paige | ...

hints.content: Each student in the population has an equal chance of being in the sample.
**This is random sampling.**

question.content:
Willy wants to find what percent of students at his school drink the milk after they finish their cereal.  He randomly selects $50$ student names from a hat. 

**What type of sampling is this?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content: The students are in order and every $\text{n}^{\text{th}}$ student is included in the sample.
**This is systematic sampling.**

question.content:
Willy wants to find what percent of students at his school drink the milk after they finish their cereal.  He selects every tenth person who enters the school.

**What type of sampling is this?**

[[☃ radio 2]]

hints.content: The students are separated into groups (grade levels) and a random sample of students is taken from each group. Those samples are put together to form the overall sample.
He is sampling *some* members from *all* of the groups.
**This is stratified sampling.**

question.content:
Willy wants to find what percent of students at his school drink the milk after they finish their cereal.  He randomly selects $10$ students from each grade level (freshman, sophomore, junior, senior).

**What type of sampling is this?**

[[☃ radio 2]]

hints.content: The students are separated into groups (classrooms) and some of the groups are chosen at random. All the members of those chosen groups are in the sample.
He is sampling *all* the members from *some* of the groups.
**This is cluster sampling.**

question.content:
Willy wants to find what percent of students at his school drink the milk after they finish their cereal.  He randomly selects $3$ classrooms and surveys every student in those classrooms.

**What type of sampling is this?**

[[☃ radio 2]]
